Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: My ardents spoke of one of our kin that escaped a crashing ghaik slave-vessel.
Lae'zel: Ch'r'ai. Vlaakith's justice in flesh.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much, child. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You have accomplished much since. I am pleased to finally meet you.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: I heard there is so much goblin blood on your hands that it soaks their children's nightmares.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Kith'rak Voss' made a mistake when he let you go.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: To business. I suspect you plucked something precious from the ghaik ship. Something that belongs to us.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Give it to me.
Narrator: *The artefact stirs in your pocket. Right within your grasp, and desperate not to be relinquished.*
GROUP_Daisy: Don't do it. The weapon is how I protect you.
Lae'zel: Do it. Do not disobey the Inquisitor.
Player: I can't. It protects me.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Indeed? And what does it protect you from?
Player: All kinds of bad things. It's my lucky charm.
: True
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: You really have no idea what it is, do you?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: But you were not wrong to observe that you need protection.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Once the Grand Design comes into effect and the Illithid Empire is restored, all life will be over as you know it.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: We took an interest in you when you became involved with this 'Absolute' cult. A pestilence of infected slaves - the first symptom of the Grand Design in action.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: But you are lucky - that weapon you carry is the solution. I have heard it from Queen Vlaakith herself.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Hand it over.
Player: What do I get in return if I give it to you?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The ghaik are about to execute their Grand Design and you seek to bargain. P'hak'va.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The weapon. Now.
Player: What is the Grand Design?
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: The Grand Design is what all ghaik seek. The restoration of the Illithid Empire, which spanned the entirety of the multiverse.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: For centuries, their elder brains sought to bring back their dominion. Every plot they hatched, we stopped. But now, they are close to succeeding.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Never before could they pause ceremorphosis. Never before could they let the infection spread undetected.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Imagine that everywhere. Wants, needs, choice - all would cease to be.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: Everything rendered unto the ghaik.
Ch'r'ai W'wargaz: So. The weapon. Please.
GROUP_Daisy: Don't give it to him.
Player: I won't let you take it.
Lae'zel: Do not try me. Hand over the artefact, or die by my hand.
NodeContext: Threatening and confident. She means what she says.
Player: Remember the zaith'isk? These gith can't be trusted. Follow my lead - I'll choose the right path.

Player: We were just discussing the next steps.
Shadowheart: I see.
Shadowheart: I'd be careful with Wyll.
Player: If anyone has me concerned, it's you. You haven't exactly been open about yourself.
Shadowheart: I think I've been more than candid - you know about my faith, for one thing.
Shadowheart: Either way, be careful. You never know what lengths someone might take to solve this little problem of ours.
Shadowheart: If we're to survive, we need to trust each other.
Shadowheart: And just to be clear, come daybreak, finding a healer is our first priority.
Player: Let's not abandon all caution. This is unfamiliar territory.

Wulbren Bongle: Good to see you. Wasn't sure you'd make it to the city. Regretting it yet?
Wulbren Bongle: I spent a lot of time thinking of worst case scenarios while I was locked in that cell you plucked me out of at Moonrise.
Wulbren Bongle: I didn't imagine anything as bad as this. The Gondians have handed Enver Gortash the means to bring about the end of liberty in Baldur's Gate.
Wulbren Bongle: And the citizens have rolled out the red carpet for their new tyrant.
Wulbren Bongle: Resistance fighters are few and far between - my Ironhands, what's left of the Harpers, and you. I hope.
Player: I'm with you.
Wulbren Bongle: Good. We don't have a chance unless we stick together - not while the Gondians' metal monsters are patrolling the streets.
Wulbren Bongle: The Steel Watch. They're a threat to you, me - and every man, woman and child in the city.
Wulbren Bongle: They act all civilised... servants of the people. But they only serve one man.
Wulbren Bongle: When he becomes Grand Duke, it will only get worse. Laws will change, freedoms will vanish, and soon you'll be accused and sentenced before you've even committed a crime.
Wulbren Bongle: And the fucking Gondians are to blame for all of it.
Player: The Gondians are just inventors. You can't blame them for Gortash's actions.
Wulbren Bongle: I can blame them for precisely that reason.
Player: There must be a reason the Gondians would do something so terrible.
Wulbren Bongle: Could be they're part of the cult. Could just be for coin. Couldn't possibly tell you.
Wulbren Bongle: They've always been happy to provide their technology to despots in exchange for a stipend and the freedom to work in peace.
Wulbren Bongle: They would have licked Sarevok's boots given the chance, and now they'll kiss Gortash's ring while the city screams.
Wulbren Bongle: I had a plan to put a stop to them. But the way things are now, if we stick our heads above ground, the Watchers are on us like flies on shit.
Player: I've already run foul of the Watchers myself.
Wulbren Bongle: And yet here you are, all in one piece. Most people who cross them aren't much more than a stain on the street afterwards.
Wulbren Bongle: You can do what's needed - I'm sure of it.
Wulbren Bongle: You just need a little assistance, and I can provide it.
Wulbren Bongle: The Gondians are ingenious. But we're more than equal to them - there's nothing they can build that the Ironhands can't tear down.
Wulbren Bongle: I've built something unique for just that purpose.
Wulbren Bongle: A runepowder bomb - first of its kind. Fifty wizards high on the Weave couldn't summon this kind of firepower.
Wulbren Bongle: Get the bomb inside the Gondian facility, and - boom. Problem solved.
Barcus Wroot: Wulbren, please. This is too far! Everyone in the foundry would be killed.
Wulbren Bongle: Quiet, Barcus. The adults are talking.
Player: I'll blow up the foundry - give me the bomb.

Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: Chk. Don't you dare consider it.
Player: What are you going to do with it?
Havkelaag: Study it, of course. Your kind have been a source of great debate in the Society's circles in recent months.
Havkelaag: Most on this plane believe you to be innately cruel, violent beings. Evil, if you will.
Havkelaag: As citizens of the Underdark, we face similar stigmas. Totally unfounded, of course - our natures are as unfixed as any who walk the surface.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.
Player: What does this 'intellectually stimulating' upbringing look like?
Havkelaag: In the literal sense, I will need to induce the egg to hatch via the application of certain currents to the creature inside.
Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:
Havkelaag: The enforced repetition of sound moral principles from the Ptarian code, alongside a series of psionic pulses administered to the cerebral tissue.
Havkelaag: Assuming I can accelerate its growth, I should have conclusive findings within a year or two at the most.
Player: Why follow the dogma of a draconic god?
Havkelaag: In my years of study, they're the closest I've found to moral perfection. Only under such rigorous 'goodness' will the subject stand a chance of being cured.
Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.
Player: Your findings are irrelevant, as are the opinions of all on this kaincha plane.
Havkelaag: Ah. A display of the well-known githyanki arrogance. I am not sure my experiment can cure that particular affliction, but give me time and I will find a way.
Havkelaag: Now, I'm eager to get started, so will you sell me the egg? ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])
Lae'zel: A gith hatchling is not a lab rat! This shka'keth should be bled dry for the mere suggestion.
Player: Sell the egg.
Havkelaag: Ah. Unfortunately, it seems I've mislaid my purse.
Havkelaag: I don't suppose you'd consider simply donating it to the Society instead?
Player: Fine. Here you go.

conversation:
Rugan: By the gods, you're a sweet sight.
Rugan: Are any of my crew still alive out there?
Player: No. It's a grim sight.
Rugan: This whole journey's been one grim sight after another. Gnolls, goblins... drow.
Rugan: Risen Road's more dangerous than ever. You're the first friendly face we've seen since Elturgard.
Player: Elturgard's a long way from here. Where are you heading?
Rugan: We're bound for Baldur's Gate - got some cargo to deliver. But we've a stop to make along the way.
Player: Where's that?
Rugan: Waukeen's Rest. It's just up the road. I'd be enjoying a mug of ale right now if those beasts hadn't jumped us.
Rugan: Listen. You look like you know how to handle yourself.
Rugan: You should meet my associates. We've got our own drinking spot by the tavern - invitation only.
Rugan: Tell the fellow on the door 'little serpent, long shadow'. He'll take good care of you.
Olly: Rugan!
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: Read his thoughts.
: True
Rugan: Shame we lost so many agents. But the chest is all that matters - Zarys'd have our hides if we lost it.
Rugan: It's fine. We'd be dead if they hadn't showed up. A little hospitality won't do any harm.
Player: What's in the chest? Your cargo?
Rugan: Aye. The whole reason we're in this mess. Trinkets for some rich tosser in Baldur's Gate.
Rugan: He gets his shiny baubles, we get a handful of Tarenths.
Narrator: *Tarenths are the currency of a merchant network called the Zhentarim. Led by the mysterious Pereghost of Darkhold, their dealings are far from scrupulous.*
Player: You're Zhentarim. Your people don't deal in 'baubles'.
Rugan: You know who we are - very clever. Then you probably also know it's not smart to interfere with Zhent business.
Rugan: This is the point when a clever operator like you accepts my gratitude and walks away.
Player: You'll find I'm very persuasive. We can make much more coin than you would with your employers.
: True
Rugan: I like the way you think. Didn't expect to turn this horrorshow to my advantage... but why not?
Rugan: The chest's all yours. Damn thing's sealed tighter than a Duke's pursestrings, so there's no point in trying to open it.
Rugan: I know a fence in Baldur's Gate who'll take it off your hands. Nobody will be the wiser.
Rugan: Don't try to cut me out of the deal though. The Black Network has eyes and blades everywhere.
Rugan: Crafty swine like you could make a name for yourself in the Zhentarim. Make sure to drop by our hideout.
Rugan: Pass phrase at the door is 'little serpent, long shadow'. I'll tell my associates to expect you.
Player: I already met your friends - we didn't get along too well.
Rugan: And yet here you are. There's not many cause trouble in a Zhent hideout and walk away.
Rugan: I'd rather walk away too. So let's say our goodbyes, and speak no more of it.
Player: You can leave - but your cargo stays.

GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: You came. Such a shame.
NodeContext: a sad welcome. Rhyme is intentional and playful. Speaking softly
GROUP_Act3_LOW_HouseOfHope_Hope: CURIOSITY KILLED ALL THE CATS IT WON'T BE SO KIND TO YOU
Narrator: *As the woman speaks, you hear a distant rattle of chains, and she winces in pain.*

Helsik: Your esteemedness returns! O joyous hour.
Narrator: *Raphael's warlock, Korrilla, mentioned a diabolist who aided Gortash. This cheerful woman doesn't seem the likeliest candidate.*
Player: Did you help Lord Gortash retrieve some hellish curios by any chance?
Helsik: You must be awfully familiar with our esteemed Archduke to know about a thing like that.
Helsik: Interesting. How exactly are you and our esteemed Archduke acquainted?
Player: I happened upon some of his correspondence that mentioned you dealings with him.
Helsik: Truly. That's remarkable. I like to deal with remarkable people. Very well.
Helsik: You seek answers, Lord Mammon seeks coin. I will happily mediate - make me an offer.
Karlach: Mammon! I knew it. I did!
Player: How about [GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6_ebf7de6b-4598-4feb-9c50-8083fc0fc59d] gold?
Helsik: A generous donation... The King of Avarice's pockets are most pleased.
Helsik: You stand before Mammon's Picklock. Latchkeeper of the Nine Hells. My business is not information, nor hellish curios, not really.
Helsik: I break people into the Hells. That's my thing.
Helsik: I can reveal to you that I opened a portal for Lord Gortash.
Player: Where in the hells did the portal go?
Helsik: My word... This is embarrassing. Perhaps I should have explained our terms better.
Helsik: You asked what I did for Lord Gortash, you paid the fee, and I answered you. Our pact is complete. Would you like to make another transaction?

conversation:
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. You are no sister, but that matters none. Every student is welcome.
Player: A student, yes. Do please enlighten me.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Wyll: Hells. Only a monster would inflict misery and call it medicine.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: But you: look how the succour of Shar eludes you. See how painfully present you remain...
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.
Player: Your subject is tainted. Shar's succour must only be granted to the willing.
Malus Thorm: Hmmm. 'Only the willing may know the Lady's embrace.' You know her teachings well.
Malus Thorm: And yet, these sisters must exercise their gifts, for the art of absence lies in its execution.
Malus Thorm: How to proceed, I wonder.
Player: In my years of study, I have found no better teacher than example. Perhaps you could volunteer?
: True
Malus Thorm: I see now. By example I must edify and quell the light that blinds us.

Duke Ulder Ravengard: Be in awe, Truest Soul. The new dawn will rise.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Have you come to behold the new dawn?
Player: I'm here to help you. Florrick sent me.
Duke Ulder Ravengard: Help me? Ah - the black widow caught you in her web.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We see the Surgeon stand by a table upon which a wriggling human lies strapped down in an X position. Several Darkcloak sisters stand by, each with a scalpel in hand. The surgeon’s voice is very gentle - the voice of a father explaining something to his young child.
Malus Thorm: The objective of the scalpel, sisters, is to soothe, for the scalpel, indeed, is an extension of Shar.
Malus Thorm: See how the patient reacts when I but stroke the right nerve. Hear its comfort. Hear the very melody of mercy.
Malus Thorm: Pray, sister, show us the extent of your beneficence.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The Darkcloak sister approaches - she looks uncertain of herself. She cuts into the human’s belly, but it’s a superficial and hesitant incision. The humann clenches its teeth and hisses in pain, but nothing like when the Surgeon applied his scalpel-finger.
Malus Thorm: Stop. Stay your hand, for it slaps where it should stroke. We can hardly hear the patient's sighs of solace.
Malus Thorm: Perhaps it is our unexpected audience that makes you quiver.
Malus Thorm: Come. Step forward. I can see the love of Shar darken your eyes. Be welcome.
Player: May Shar guide your blessing hands.
Malus Thorm: And the rough vessels that are yours.
Malus Thorm: Tell me, what is the guiding principle of the goddess?
Player: Darkness.
Malus Thorm: I profess there is another more profound.
Sister Hunna: Absence.
Malus Thorm: Absence. No other word captures the heart of Shar so very perfectly.
Malus Thorm: It is the scalpel-led journey that leads from pain to peace.
Lae'zel: Only a beast of a man toys with his victim. Entertaining, if not efficient.
Malus Thorm: See? What is the light of eyes but the cancer that causes one to witness the laceration of being?
Malus Thorm: If light is the symptom, then darkness is the cure, for in light there is presence, but in darkness there is absence.
Sister Hunna: In light is presence; in darkness, absence.
Malus Thorm: You are well on your way. But one white orb disfigures you still. Let us finish the cure.
Malus Thorm: We do not wish to see you suffer so. Let us cure you.

: True

Malus Thorm: Their incisions are, as yet, still streaked with imprecision - that much I must concede.
Malus Thorm: How to steady their hands, I wonder.
Player: Practice - that's how I got good with a blade. They should spar each other.

Malus Thorm: Yes... For are we not all in need of a cure?
Malus Thorm: The scalpel does not discriminate. Let each and every one of you partake in its soothing journey.
Malus Thorm: Absence, sisters. Acquaint yourselves.

Havkelaag: Well met. What can the Society of Brilliance do for you?
Havkelaag: Tell me, what can the Society do for you?
Player: I carry an unhatched githyanki egg. Would you be interested in studying it?
Havkelaag: A githyanki egg? What a fortuitous turn of events. I've been attempting to get my hands on one for some time now.
Havkelaag: Would you consider parting with it? The Society's coffers are deep enough to cover any expenses accrued in its retrieval, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Player: What are you going to do with it?

Havkelaag: You are no doubt aware that citizens of the Underdark are held in great suspicion by those who live above ground. Many believe us to be 'evil'.
Havkelaag: The githyanki face similar prejudice, but I believe, if hatched in a less violent, more intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome its evil predispositions.
Havkelaag: I believe that, if hatched in a morally sound, intellectually stimulating environment, the child can overcome the evil predisposition its githyanki nature bestows.

Havkelaag: Once out of the shell, I plan to take a twofold approach:

Havkelaag: My findings could change the perception of githyanki and the peoples of the Underdark for generations to come.

Player: You'll need to find him without my help - I've done all I can for now.

Player: I see some familiar faces, but where's everyone else?
Alfira: You don't know? Stars above...
Alfira: We were ambushed out in the darkness - by cultists. We surrendered, but that wasn't enough for them.
Alfira: They lined us up like dogs. Ikaron was with the kids, telling them it was gonna be all right.

Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.
Player: Which one was Asharak again?
Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.
Player: You're lucky to be alive.
Alfira: I don't feel lucky. I feel... I feel like I'm at the end of my rope.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?
Player: It helps to remember what is at stake - I fight for nature, for balance. I fight for life itself.
Alfira: You're made of sterner stuff than me then.
Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.
Player: I'll do everything in my power to save them - you have my most solemn vow.

Narrator: *As you get closer to the printworks, something odd happens. You hear it speak.*
Printing Press: Oi, gormless - not one step further! You are interrupting art.
: True
Narrator: *You feel a dancing, mischievous magic sparking through air around the printer. A fey creature resides within.*
Player: A talking printer? Fey magic never ceases to amaze.
Printing Press: Are you addled in the head? I am no chattering contraption, I am a person. An artist. Name's Jelliwig.
Printing Press: This is my paintbrush. I make sure everything that's in those big ugly article blocks becomes fine printed artistry. I'm a master pensman, I am.
Printing Press: Now scram it. One mistake and the reputation of Baldur's Mouth Gazette crumbles to dust.
Player: I agree. The right words at the right time - literal magic. We're alike, you and I.
: True
Printing Press: Ahah, someone who appreciates the art of words. And a celebrity to boot. You'll enjoy this.
Printing Press: As it happens, the next edition has an article about you. Ooh, it's a mean one, too - real nasty. Ettvard must really have it out for you. Hard luck.
Printing Press: Will require a delicate touch to spruce up. Think I'll need my number seven pen. Real sharp.
Player: You need to stop it from being printed.
Printing Press: I'm afraid I can't help you. I've got a good thing going here - letting you swap out a whole article might get Ettvard suspicious.
Printing Press: I wouldn't take it too personal. Ettvard gets his lines from up top, then gets all worked up over it.
Printing Press: Although, it not being personal doesn't change how shafted you'll be.
Player: Wouldn't changing the article be delightfully naughty?
: True
Printing Press: A-ha! A meddler after my own heart - wonderful.
